question.title: Can't convert Supplier<S> into Supplier<?>
question.body:
I have a very simple Java class that looks like this

public class StatementRegister {
    public static final Map<String, Supplier<Statement<?>>> registry = new HashMap<>();

    public static <R> Supplier<Statement<R>> register(String id, Supplier< Statement<R>> statement) {
        Supplier<Statement<R>> registry_value = () -> statement.get().withID(id);
        registry.put(id,registry_value);
        return registry_value;
    }
}

However, it won't let me put registry_value inside of of the hash map, can't convert from Supplier<ScriptStatement<R>> to Supplier<ScriptStatement<?>>.

Now, I understand, at least broadly, why this is problematic, I don't know what DataType I will be pulling out of the hash map, but I can't figure out a good alternative, I have tried refactoring my code to look a little like this for example:

public class StatementRegister {
    public static final Map<String, StatementType<?,?>> registry = new HashMap<>();

    public static <R> Supplier<Statement<R>> register(Class<T> return_type, Supplier<S> constructor, BiFunction<ScriptCallContext,S,T> code) {
        Supplier<Statement<R>> registry_value = () -> statement.get().withID(id);
        registry.put(id,new StatementType<>(return_type,statement));
        return registry_value;
    }

    public record StatementType<T,S extends Statement<T>>(Class<T> return_type, Supplier<S> constructor, BiFunction<ScriptCallContext,S,T> code) {}
}

This creates a number of new abstraction problems.

Basically, what I am trying to do is fairly straightforward, I am trying to create a registry of instructions where each instruction is a function that can be serialised and deserialised and store some data like parameters and such, but it's doing my head in.

answers.body:
In general, what you're trying to do can't be made type-safe, so you might as well do unsafe casts everywhere.

That said, what you need is almost certainly Map<String, Supplier<? extends Statement<?>>>, and you can assign a Supplier<Statement<R>> to a Supplier<? extends Statement<?>>.

You can try doing a hybrid. Build a registry of serializable/deserializable instructions. And make them dynamic.

public class StatementRegister {
    private static final Map<String, Supplier<? extends Statement<?>>> registry = new HashMap<>();

    public static <R> Supplier<Statement<R>> register(String id, Supplier<Statement<R>> statement) {
        Supplier<Statement<R>> registryValue = () -> statement.get().withID(id);
        registry.put(id, registryValue);
        return registryValue;
    }

    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
    public static <R> Supplier<Statement<R>> get(String id) {
        return (Supplier<Statement<R>>) registry.get(id);
    }
}

You don't need to use unnecessary abstraction, you can still store everything that is implemented with Statement<T> regardless of T.
